Research Center for Gold Chemistry Department of Applied Chemistry for Environment Graduate School of Urban Environmental Sciences Tokyo Metropolitan University 1-1 Minami-osawa Hachioji Tokyo 192-0397 Japan Graphical abstract We prepared a series of Nb2O5 polymorphs by the sol-gel method and the sol-gel hydrothermal method. Gold nanoparticles supported on Nb2O5 were prepared by solid grinding method. Au on pseudohexagonal (TT-phase) Nb2O5 containing an amorphous phase exhibited higher catalytic activity for CO oxidation than did other Au/Nb2O5 polymorphs. For the electrochemical properties for cathode materials of Li-ion batteries, Nb2O5 (TT) exhibited high capacity of 208 mA h g-1, and the deposition of Au onto Nb2O5 (TT) improved the capacity to 232 mA h g-1. Capacity and CO oxidation activity were related; the higher the catalytic activity Au/Nb2O5 shows, the higher is the discharging capacity. From the characterization results, Nb2O5 (TT) contains oxygen vacancies (Nb4+ sites), and the oxygen vacancies of Nb2O5 (TT) would play an important role for CO oxidation and the performance for Li-ion batteries. Keywords Gold nanoparticles niobium oxide CO oxidation Li-ion batteries 1 Introduction Recently, much attention worldwide has been given to climate change and energy shortage, and the development of environmental protection and renewable energy technologies has been accelerated. For this purpose, research on advanced functional materials for electrocatalysis and energy storage has gained increasing attention [1,2]. In particular, Li-ion batteries have been intensively studied. The performance of these functional materials is strongly dependent on efficient intercalation and transport of electrons and ions [3,4]. Therefore, recent studies have focused on the design of novel nanostructured materials with enhanced electric conductivity and intercalation properties. Niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5) has shown superior performance for catalysis, photocatalysis, supercapacitors, Li-ion batteries, and solar cells owing to its unique chemical and physical properties, various polymorphic forms, various morphologies, abundance in nature, and low toxicity [5–11]. Although stoichiometric Nb2O5 is an insulator (electrical conductivity, σ ∼3 × 10−6 S cm−1), it becomes an n-type semiconductor (σ ∼3 × 10−3 S cm−1) under oxygen-deficient conditions [12]. Consequently, batteries using Nb2O5 cathodes have limitations of their electrochemical utilization and high-rate capacity due to the ohmic polarization and ion diffusion constraints. Many efforts have been devoted to improving the electrochemical performance by methods such as mixing with transition metals, coating with metal oxides, and controlling morphologies and structures of Nb2O5 [9]. The creation of oxygen vacancies in metal oxides such as Nb2O5 [12], TiO2 [13,14], MnO2 [15], MoO3 [16], and V2O5 [17] is one of the most promising methods for improving the electrochemical performance. Heat treatment of metal oxides is a simple and efficient method for creating oxygen vacancies, and deposition of gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) is an alternative method [18,19]. The combination of high electrical conductivity of Au and creation of a large amount of oxygen vacancies is expected to improve the catalytic activity for oxidation reactions and the electrochemical properties. Our recent work revealed that Nb2O5-supported Au NPs (Au/Nb2O5) were highly active catalysts for CO oxidation at room temperature [20]. In this work, we modified the methods for preparation of Nb2O5 and we applied the obtained Au/Nb2O5 to cathode materials for Li-ion batteries. Au deposited on pseudohexagonal Nb2O5 prepared by the sol-gel method exhibited higher catalytic activity than Au on other Nb2O5 polymorphs for CO oxidation at a low temperature, and the temperature at 50% conversion (T50) was recorded to be 45 °C. Au/Nb2O5 (pseudohexagonal, TT-phase) also exhibited higher electrochemical performance than that of other Au/Nb2O5 samples and Nb2O5 samples without Au for Li-ion batteries. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of Nb2O5 and Nb2O5-Supported Gold Nanoparticles 2.1.1 Materials All reagents (2-(p-tolyl)pyridine, trifluoroacetic acid, potassium tert-butoxide (KO t Bu), ammonium niobate(V) oxalate hydrate, gold(III) acetate, dichloromethane, hexane, and diethyl ether) were purchased and used without further purifications. Amorphous Nb2O5-A (JRC-NbO-1, reference catalyst) was supplied from the Catalysis Society of Japan). 2.1.2 Preparation of Nb2O5 Nb2O5 polymorphs were prepared by sol-gel and sol-gel hydrothermal with normal and rapid heat treatments. Sol-gel method. In a typical procedure, 5 g of ammonium niobate(V) oxalate hydrate (NH4[NbO(C2O4)2(H2O)2·nH2O, 99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to 1.2 mL of 1 M citric acid aqueous solution, and the mixture was ground in an agate mortar in air at room temperature for 10 min. The paste was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 8 h, and a white gel was obtained. Finally, the gel was ground until it became white powder and the powder was calcined by the heat treatment described below. Sol-gel hydrothermal method. In a typical procedure, the gel obtained by using the above-described sol-gel method was ground to form white powder, transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and then heated at 175 °C for 24 h in a static condition. After cooling down to room temperature in a water bath, a powder was obtained by filtration and washing with water. After drying at 80 °C overnight, the powder was ground to form white particles and the particles were calcined by the heat treatment described below. Normal heat treatment. The white powder and the white particles obtained by the sol-gel and sol-gel hydrothermal methods, respectively, were heated in air at 300 °C for 2 h with a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1. Rapid heat treatment. The white powder and the white particles obtained by the sol-gel and sol-gel hydrothermal methods were placed in an alumina crucible. The samples were placed in a furnace that had been pre-heated to 800 °C for 5 min. After an appropriate time interval, the samples were quickly taken out from the furnace and were left to cool on a benchtop. Nb2O5-1 was prepared by the sol-gel method followed by rapid heat treatment. Nb2O5-2 was prepared by the sol-gel hydrothermal method followed by rapid heat treatment. Nb2O5-3 was prepared by the sol-gel method followed by normal thermal treatment. Nb2O5-4 was prepared by the sol-gel hydrothermal method followed by normal thermal treatment. Hydrothermal method [21]. Ammonium niobium(V) oxalate (NH4[NbO(C2O4)2(H2O)2·nH2O, 99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in distilled water, and the solution was treated by hydrothermal synthesis at 175 °C for 1 day. The resultant solid was separated and washed with distilled water under filtration, and the solid was dried at 80 °C. The dried solid was crushed in an agate mortar and treated in air at 400 °C for 2 h to give Nb2O5-L. 2.1.3 Synthesis of a Gold Complex (AuTFA) The complex AuTFA was prepared according to the literature [22] with a minor modification. A solution of gold(III) acetate (0.128 g, 0.34 mmol) and 2-(p-tolyl)pyridine (70 μL, 0.41 mmol, 1.19 eq.) dissolved in a 1:1 mixture of water (5.0 mL) and trifluoroacetic acid (5.0 mL) was heated in an oil bath at 140 °C for 6 h. After the reaction, the light yellow solution was cooled to room temperature for 30 min and was then decanted into a round bottom flask. When the product had been precipitated, trifluoroacetic acid was added to redissolve the product before decanting in order to remove a small amount of unreacted Au(OAc)3. The product was precipitated by adding water while cooling. The precipitate was collected on a fine frit, washed with water (3 × 2 mL) and diethyl ether (2 mL), and dried in air at 80 °C for 40 min. The product was obtained in 90% yield. An analytical sample was obtained by recrystallization from a mixture of dichloromethane and hexane. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD2Cl2, δ in ppm): δ 8.41 (dd, J = 6.3, 0.9 Hz, 1 H), 8.08 (dt, J = 7.6, 1.5 Hz, 1 H), 7.76 (dd, J = 8.3, 1.1 Hz, 1 H), 7.37 (ddd, J = 7.5, 6.0, 1.4 Hz, 1 H), 7.31 (d, J =7.8 Hz, 1 H), 7.16 (ddd, J = 8.0, 1.4, 0.6 Hz, 1 H), 6.76 (s, 1 H), 2.44 (s, 3 H). Anal. Calcd for C16H10AuF6NO4: C, 32.51; H, 1.70; N, 2.37. Found: C, 32.44; H, 1.70; N, 2.43. 2.1.4 Preparation of Nb2O5-Supported Gold Nanoparticles Solid grinding (SG) was used to deposit Au particles on various Nb2O5 polymorphs with 1 wt% of initial Au loading [23–25]. Nb2O5 (0.5 g) and AuTFA (15.4 mg) were ground in an agate mortar in air for 10 min at room temperature. KO t Bu (29 mg, 2 wt%) was added to the mixture, and then the mixture was ground in air for another 10 min. Then the mixture was calcined at 300 °C for 2 h. 2.2 Characterization Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) speciﬁc surface area was obtained by nitrogen adsorption measurements. The samples were pretreated under vacuum at 200 °C for 2 h. Then N2 adsorption isotherms were measured at −196 °C with a MicrotracBEL Corp. Bellsorp. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-ﬁeld scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) observations were carried out using a JEOL JEM-3200FS at 300 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried using a ULVAC PHI 500 (Versa Probe II) equipped with a monochromatic Al K α (1486.6 eV) X-ray source. The photoelectron signals were collected in the constant pass energy mode using a concentric hemispherical energy analyzer that was calibrated with pure gold, silver, and copper standard samples by setting the Au 4f 7/2, Ag 3d 5/2, and Cu 2p 3/2 peaks at binding energies of 83.96 ± 0.02 eV, 368.21 ± 0.02 eV, and 932.62 ± 0.02 eV, respectively. Binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C 1 s binding energy of adventitious carbon contamination taken to be 284.6 eV. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed with a Rigaku Corporation RINT-TTR III diffractometer at a scanning rate of 2° min−1 and a sampling angle interval of 0.02° in 2θ ranging from 10° to 70° with high-intensity Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.151478 nm). The operating voltage and current were 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. The phase of components was identified by matching diffraction patterns to the JCPDS powder diffraction file. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL ECS-300 (300 MHz for 1H) spectrometer in CD2Cl2 (Acros Organics Co., Inc.) with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra were recorded on a JASCO FT/IR-620 equipped with a heat chamber (ST Japan, Model HC500). A background spectrum was collected with 100 scans at 4 cm−1 resolution. The sample was pretreated with 20 vol% O2 in N2 (50 mL min−1) at 250 °C for 1 h. Then the sample was exposed to 10 vol% CO in He (40 mL min−1) and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra were obtained by subtracting the background spectrum from subsequent spectra at −190 °C. The actual gold loading was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) by using a Shimadzu AA-6200 after dissolving Au by aqua regia. 2.3 Catalytic Tests Catalytic tests for CO oxidation were carried out in a ﬁxed-bed glass reactor containing 0.15 g of a catalyst sample (weight hour space velocity (WHSV) = 20,000 mL h−1 gcat −1). A reaction gas containing 1 vol% CO in air was fed directly from the cylinder without puriﬁcation. In all cases, pretreatment was performed at 250 °C for 1 h in a stream of dry air at a ﬂow rate of 50 mL min−1. After the pretreatment, the catalyst sample was cooled down to room temperature and then the feed gas was switched to the reaction gas under a total pressure of 0.1 MPa at various temperatures. The inlet and outlet gases were analyzed with on-line gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-8A equipped with a TCD and a molecular sieve 13X column) to obtain both the conversion of CO and the yield of CO2. For CO oxidation in humid air, CO oxidation was performed by Microtrac BEL Corp. Belcat II with a mass spectrometer (BEL Mass). The catalyst (0.15 g) was placed in a glass cell, pretreated in air (50 mL min−1) at 250 °C for 1 h. After the pretreatment, the catalyst was cooled to room temperature, and the reaction gas (1 vol% in air) containing water (0–2 vol%) (50 mL min−1) was passed through the glass cell at 40 °C. 2.4 Electrochemical Tests Electrochemical performances of Nb2O5 and Au/Nb2O5 were investigated using coin-type cells (CR2032) [26–30]. The working electrodes were composed of 80 wt% active materials, 10 wt% poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE) as a binder, and 10 wt% acetylene black. These materials were ground in an agate mortar to make electrode paste. The prepared paste was spread uniformly, rolling into a sheet, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 160 °C for 4 h. The cathode sheet was punched into circular discs and cut into wafers (7 mm in diameter, 0.025 mm in thickness, 5–6 mg). The tested cell was assembled inside an argon-filled glove box. For electrochemical measurements, the cell was composed of lithium metal counter, reference electrodes, and a positive electrode. The cathode and reference electrodes were separated by a microporous polypropylene film. The electrolyte consisted of a solution of 1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC) (1/1 by volume) (Tomiyama Pure Chemical Co., Ltd.). Charge-discharge cycling was performed galvanostatically between 1.0 and 2.5 V vs Li/Li+ on multi-channel battery testers (Hokuto Denko, Japan) at various charge/discharge rates ranging from 0.1 to 10 C. Current densities and specific capacities were calculated on the basis of the weight of the Nb2O5 cathode in the electrode. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Crystalline Phase and Morphology of Au/Nb2O5 Several kinds of Nb2O5 supports were prepared by different methods: sol-gel and sol-gel hydrothermal methods with different heat treatments. The physicochemical properties of Nb2O5 obtained are shown in Table 1 , and XRD patterns are shown in Fig. S1. The reported sol-gel process was performed with niobium alkoxides or niobium chlorides and the gradual formation of a gel-like network [6,9], and we modified the process by using ammonium niobate(V) oxalate hydrate as a precursor and fast formation of a gel-like network followed by calcination at 800 °C and 300 °C to obtain Nb2O5-1 and Nb2O5-3, respectively. BET surface areas of Nb2O5-1 and Nb2O5-3 were 25 and 2.4 m2 g−1, respectively. The diffraction pattern of Nb2O5-1 was consistent with that of JCPDS 28-0317 and was assigned to pseudohexagonal, so-called TT-phase, with a small halo pattern (Fig. S1) [9,20]. No clear diffraction peaks of Nb2O5-3 were observed, suggesting that an amorphous component was a major species (Fig. S1). Nb2O5-2 and -4 were prepared by the sol-gel hydrothermal method followed by calcination at 800 °C and 300 °C, respectively. The positions of the diffraction peaks of Nb2O5-2 were almost the same as those of Nb2O5-1, but the difference was observed in the range of 27–30°; two peaks were observed at 28.5 and 28.9° for Nb2O5-2, while only a single peak was observed for Nb2O5-1 at 28.5° as shown in Fig. 1 . Therefore, the diffraction pattern of Nb2O5-2 was assigned to orthorhombic, so-called T-phase (abbreviated as T, JCPDS 30-0873). Nb2O5-4 showed diffraction peaks at 22.7° and 46.2° and a halo peak corresponding to an amorphous component (Fig. S1). The former peaks were observed at positions similar to (001) and (002) of TT-phase and T-phase, and were assigned to a layered-type structure in which NbO6 octahedra were corner-sharing in the c-direction [20,31]. The surface areas of Nb2O5-2 and -4 were calculated to be 63 and 235 m2 g−1, respectively, which were higher than those of Nb2O5-1 and -3. We also examined a commercial amorphous Nb2O5 having high surface area, abbreviated as Nb2O5-A, and layered-type Nb2O5 prepared by hydrothermal method, abbreviated as Nb2O5-L, as supports for Au NPs. The XRD peaks of Nb2O5-L were observed at 22.7 and 46.2°, which were assigned to (001) and (002) planes of the layered-type structure [32]. The deposition of Au particles onto Nb2O5 was performed by SG using a non-volatile organogold complex, AuTFA [24]. XRD patterns of Au/Nb2O5 are shown in Figs. 1 and S2. Compared with the XRD patterns of Nb2O5 (Fig. S1), the deposition of Au onto Nb2O5 polymorphs did not induce a change in the crystalline structures of Nb2O5. For Au/Nb2O5-1, no diffraction peak corresponding to Au was observed (Fig. 1). After the deposition of Au, two tiny peaks were newly observed at 2θ = 38.2° and 44.4° for other Au/Nb2O5 catalysts (Figs. 1 and S2) and were assigned to the (111) and (200) lattice planes of a face-centered cubic (fcc)-structured Au (JCPDS 04-0784). However, the size of Au NPs could not be estimated by XRD due to very small peaks and was estimated by TEM observation. Typical TEM images of Au/Nb2O5 polymorphs together with their corresponding Au particle size distributions are shown in Fig. 2 , and TEM images of Nb2O5-1 and -2 are shown in Fig. S3. TEM images and the size distributions of other Au/Nb2O5 samples are shown in Figs. S4 and S5. Lattice fringes with d spacing of 0.39 nm of Au/Nb2O5-1 and Au/Nb2O5-2 were consistent with a (001) planar spacing, suggesting that the (001) plane of Nb2O5 are well grown [7]. A TEM image also revealed that Nb2O5-1 has a rough surface (depressed areas of 1–6 nm in diameter) (Fig. 2a). This would be due to the removal of water and coordinating organic compounds by the rapid heat treatment, leading to an increase in the surface area to stabilize Au particles. The mean diameters of Au particles estimated by TEM were summarized in Table 1. The mean diameters of Au NPs of Au/Nb2O5-1, -2, and -4 were similar and were estimated to be 3.6 ± 1.3, 3.4 ± 0.5, 3.0 ± 0.7 nm, respectively. The size of the Au NPs of Au/Nb2O5-3 (6.9 ± 1.4 nm) was much larger than those of other Au/Nb2O5 catalysts, which was probably due to the very low surface area (Table 1, entry 3). The Au particle size of Au/Nb2O5-L was estimated to be 5.1 ± 2.5 nm, which was also relatively large despite large surface area. This is likely related to the amount of surface acid sites. In the SG method, KO t Bu was used after the grinding of AuTFA and Nb2O5. We have reported that KO t Bu neutralized the oxide support surface and promoted the decomposition of AuTFA adsorbed on supports during calcination, which gives small Au NPs [24]. Given that Nb2O5-L had a higher amount of acid sites on the surface than other Nb2O5 polymorphs (Table S1), the neutralization of the Nb2O5-L surface was not insufficient during grinding of KO t Bu and AuTFA/Nb2O5, and it led to the aggregation of Au particles. 3.2 Catalytic Activity of Nb2O5-Supported Gold Nanoparticles The catalytic activities of Au/Nb2O5 were evaluated by CO oxidation. The results are shown in Fig. 3 and summarized in Table 1. Catalytic activities of Au/Nb2O5 were compared by the temperatures of 50% CO conversion, T50 values. Au/Nb2O5-3 showed no catalytic activity less than 150 °C and the T50 value of Au/Nb2O5-L was much higher than those of other Au/Nb2O5 catalysts due to the large Au NP sizes (entries 3 and 6). Among the Au/Nb2O5 catalysts tested, Au/Nb2O5-1 (TT) exhibited higher catalytic activity than Au/Nb2O5-2 (T), Au/Nb2O5-4 (amorphous, layered-type), and Au/Nb2O5-A (amorphous). These results suggested that the catalytic activities of Au/Nb2O5 were influenced by the size of Au NPs and crystalline structures of Nb2O5. We previously reported the effect of crystalline structures of Nb2O5 and showed that the catalytic activity for CO oxidation was in the order of layered-type (deformed orthorhombic, DO) (Table 1, entry 5) > T-Phase (entry 7) > TT-Phase (entry 6) [20]. This was probably due to the fact that Nb2O5 (DO) has more flexible lattice oxygen which can be related to the redox property than do Nb2O5 (TT) and Nb2O5 (T). In addition, Nb2O5 (T) has the most rigid structure that octahedral NbO6 unit is present between the layered structures, while Nb2O5 (TT) does not (Fig. S6). Therefore, Nb2O5 polymorphs having relatively flexible lattice oxygen are more suitable supports than those having rigid crystalline structures. It is because of that the oxygen vacancy of metal oxide supports plays an important role for O2 activation in Au-catalyzed CO oxidation. The lower catalytic activity of Au/Nb2O5-L than Au/Nb2O5 (DO) [20] was ascribed to larger Au NPs deposited by SG. Instead, Au/Nb2O5-1 (TT) in this work exhibited higher catalytic activity than did Au/Nb2O5 (TT) that we previously reported. We adopted a rapid heat treatment (800 °C for 5 min) or calcination at a relatively low temperature (300 °C for 2 h) for the preparation of Nb2O5, resulting in the mixtures of crystalline structures and amorphous component, while Nb2O5 samples in the previous work were calcined at 400 °C for 2 h to give fully crystalline materials. The catalytic activity of Au/Nb2O5-A was comparable to those of Au/Nb2O5-2 and -4, suggesting that the amorphous Nb2O5 with a high surface area had sufficient amount of oxygen atoms that can be removed to form oxygen vacancy sites in Nb2O5. Therefore, the metastable Nb2O5 structure in the amorphous components in Nb2O5-1 would contribute to serving the oxygen vacancy sites for O2 activation in CO oxidation. Although the catalytic activity of Au/Nb2O5-1 was lower than that of Au/Nb2O5 (DO), rapid heat treatment at 800 °C greatly shortened the calcination time. Long-term stability of Au/Nb2O5-1 for CO oxidation was examined in a constant flow of the reaction gas as shown in Fig. S7. The catalyst was gradually deactivated within 7 h at 80 °C, which is probably due to the accumulation of carbonate species. After 17 h of CO oxidation, Au/Nb2O5-1 was treated in air (50 mL min−1) at 250 °C for 2 h, and the catalytic activity was recovered, suggesting that the carbonate species might be removed from the catalyst surface. We checked the catalytic activity of Au/Nb2O5-1 stored for one month and confirmed that the catalytic activity was maintained (Fig. S8). We also examined the effect of water for CO oxidation over Au/Nb2O5-1, and the results are shown in Fig. S9. Compared to the conversion (34%) at 40 °C under the dry condition, the addition of water from 0.5 to 2% into reaction gas did not affect the catalytic activity. Although the catalytic activity of Au/TiO2 significantly decreased from dry condition to 1 vol% water concentration [24], Au/Nb2O5-1 retained its catalytic activity under humid air. Au/Nb2O5-1 and Au/Nb2O5-2 were further characterized by XPS to investigate the oxidation states of Au and Nb (Fig. 4 ). The BEs of Nb5+ and Nb4+ in Nb2O5 have been reported to be 206.9–207.1 [12,33–35] and 205.4–205.6 eV [34,35], respectively. In our previous work, the Nb 3d5/2 peak was observed at 207.1 eV for Au/Nb2O5 with TT- and T-phases [20]. Deconvolution of the Nb 3d5/2 peaks resulted in two peaks for both Au/Nb2O5-1 and -2 (Fig. 4a and b). The peaks at higher BEs corresponding to Nb5+ were observed at 206.8 and 207.3 eV for Au/Nb2O5-1 and -2, respectively. The peak of Au/Nb2O5-1 was slightly shifted toward lower BE, compared to that of Au/Nb2O5-2. The peaks at lower BEs were attributed to Nb4+, and the peaks were observed at 204.9 and 205.3 eV for Au/Nb2O5-1 and -2, respectively. The shift of Nb5+ peak toward lower energy and the presence of Nb4+ suggest that Nb in Au/Nb2O5-1 was more negatively charged than that in Nb2O5-2, probably due to a formation of oxygen vacancies. O 1 s XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 4c and d. The peaks at lower BE (529.7 and 530.1 eV for Au/Nb2O5-1 and -2, respectively) were assignable to the lattice oxygen of Nb2O5. The small peaks at higher BE (531.6 and 532.0 eV for Au/Nb2O5-1 and -2, respectively) were reported to be oxygen in surface hydroxy groups [35]. The ratios of the lattice oxygen/surface OH were calculated to be 88/12 and 92/8 for Au/Nb2O5-1 and -2, respectively. The results suggested that Au/Nb2O5-1 contained a slightly higher amount of labile oxygen atoms on the surface than did Au/Nb2O5-2. These results agree with the catalytic activity of Au/Nb2O5-1 for CO oxidation; the higher the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst is, the higher is the catalytic activity for CO oxidation. For Au 4f XPS spectra, the Au 4f7/2 peaks of Au/Nb2O5-1 and Au/Nb2O5-2 were 83.1 and 83.8 eV, respectively. The results suggested that Au NPs on Nb2O5-1 were negatively charged. Our preparation method, SG, used KO t Bu during grinding with AuTFA adsorbed on Nb2O5. Basic KO t Bu would neutralize the acidic sites of Nb2O5 surface, which would probably generate nucleophilic O− species. Electron transfer might occur from such electron-sufficient oxygen species to Au NPs, resulting in the negatively charged species. To obtain more information on the chemical states of the Au catalysts, we performed DRIFT using CO as a probe molecule. The results are shown in Fig. 5 and summarized in Table 2 . Peaks attributed to CO adsorbed on Nb2O5 were observed at 2153 and 2151 cm−1 for Au/Nb2O5-2 and Au/Nb2O5-1, respectively. An obvious shift toward a lower wavenumber was observed compared with Au/Nb2O5-DO (2175 cm−1) [20]. This result implies a change in the oxidation state of Nb2O5, being consistent with the XPS results showing an increased Nb4+ in Au/Nb2O5-1. An absorption peak of CO adsorbed on Au NPs was observed at 2099 cm−1 for Au/Nb2O5-1, and this was assigned as CO on metallic Au0 [36]. A comparison of the wavenumber of the CO absorption peak for Au/Nb2O5-1 (2099 cm−1) with those for Au/Nb2O5-2 (2128 cm−1) and Au/Nb2O5-DO (2130, 2116 cm−1) [20] suggested that Au NPs of Au/Nb2O5-1 were more negatively charged than those of Au/Nb2O5-2. These results are consistent with the XPS results. 3.3 Electrochemical Performance of Nb2O5 and Au/Nb2O5 Nanoparticles The synthesized Nb2O5 and Au/Nb2O5 samples were examined as electrode materials for Li-ion batteries. The electrochemical performance was measured by the galvanostatic charge-discharge method. Typical charge and discharge curves, cyclic voltammogram curves, and rate performance with a cut-off voltage window of 1.0 to 2.5 V are shown in Fig. 6 . Nb2O5-1 and Au/Nb2O5-1 exhibited high discharge capacities such as 230 and 250 mA h g–1 at C/10 at the first cycle, respectively (Fig. 6a and c). Discharge capacities reached plateau slightly in the range of 1.8–1.5 V vs. Li/Li+, indicating an intercalation reaction of Li-ion with the Nb2O5 host. Fig. 6b and d show cyclic voltammograms of Nb2O5-1 and Au/Nb2O5-1 at a sweeping rate of 0.1 mV s–1. Nb2O5 exhibited oxidation/reduction voltages at 1.90 V/1.80 and 1.50 V. Fig. 6e shows typical charge/discharge profiles of Nb2O5-1 and Au/Nb2O5-1 at current rates ranging from C/10 to 10 C. Although the capacities of Nb2O5-1 and Au/Nb2O5-1 decreased from 230 to 208 and from 250 to 232 mA h g–1 at the second cycle at C/10, respectively, they showed good cyclabilities: the capacities were maintained from the second cycle for more than 40 cycles. When the C-rate was increased to 1 C, Au/Nb2O5-1 presented a discharge capacity of ca. 202.2 mA h g–1 and retained 87.2% of the capacity at C/10. Nb2O5-1 exhibited comparable reversible capacities at low C-rates. However, at higher C-rates, Au/Nb2O5-1 showed much higher discharge capacities of 169.7 mA h g–1 and 132.2 mA h g–1 at C-rates of 5 C and 10 C than those (122.0 and 52.7 mA h g–1) of Nb2O5-1. Moreover, the Au/Nb2O5-1 electrode showed higher Coulombic efficiency (CE) during the charge/discharge process, indicating less pseudocapacitive contribution. Nb2O5 is known to be a cathode material for Li-ion batteries, so that Nb2O5 played a major role in electrochemical properties. Deposition of Au onto Nb2O5 improved the capacity by 10%, and the performance of the Au/Nb2O5-1 electrode was better than those of other Nb2O5 materials reported to date. The improved electrode performance of Au/Nb2O5-1 compared to that of Nb2O5-1 without Au is presumably due to its improved electrical conductivity by the deposition of Au NPs. The electrochemical performance of other Au/Nb2O5 electrodes is shown in Figs. S10 and 11, and in Table 3 . The discharge capacities of Au/Nb2O5 (-1, -2, and -4) obtained at the steady state were 232, 188, and 211 mA h g–1 respectively, and Au/Nb2O5-1 exhibited the best performance. Au/Nb2O5-4 also showed high discharge capacity due to its high specific surface area, which allowed better contact with the electrolyte. It was also found that the electrochemical performance of Au/Nb2O5 depends on the oxidation state of Nb in Nb2O5 and the concentration of oxygen vacancies. Our preliminary tests showed that Au/Nb2O5-1 exhibited the highest intercalation capacity, good cyclability, and high-rate performance for Li-ion battery cathode among the reported values [10,37,38]. Many factors affect the catalytic activity of Au catalysts for CO oxidation and the performance for Li-ion batteries such as size of Au particles, perimeter interface between Au NPs and supports, and the kind of support (redox properties, i.e., oxygen vacancies, crystalline phase, and surface area). Oxygen vacancies have been regarded as one of the most important factors for Au-catalyzed CO oxidation. It was pointed out in several reports that oxygen vacancies made a larger interlayer spacing to enhance electrochemical properties [12–19]. In addition, the deposition of Au NPs would increase the electrical conductivity. Thus, Au/Nb2O5-1, which showed the highest catalytic activity for CO oxidation, exhibited the best performance for Li-ion batteries. 4 Conclusions We prepared several Nb2O5 materials having different crystalline phases by sol-gel and sol-gel hydrothermal methods. Rapid heat treatment at 800 °C for 5 min or heat treatment at 300 °C for 2 h gave amorphous-containing crystalline Nb2O5 or only amorphous Nb2O5. Deposition of Au NPs onto these Nb2O5 materials was performed by a SG method using a non-volatile AuTFA complex to give Au NPs of ca. 3–6 nm in diameter on the Nb2O5 materials. Au NPs on pseudohexagonal (TT-phase) Nb2O5 (Au/Nb2O5-1) exhibited higher catalytic activity for CO oxidation than did Au on orthorhombic (T-Phase) Nb2O5 (Au/Nb2O5-2), Au on a mixture of amorphous and layered Nb2O5 (Au/Nb2O5-4 and -L), and Au on amorphous Nb2O5 (Au/Nb2O5-3 and -A). The results are not consistent with the results of our previous work showing that Au on deformed T-phase Nb2O5 exhibited higher catalytic activity than that of TT-Nb2O5. Since the TT-Nb2O5 in this work (Nb2O5-1) contains amorphous components, the presence of amorphous components in TT-phase includes the metastable Nb2O5 structure, which would affect the catalytic activity for CO oxidation. Electrochemical properties of Nb2O5-1 were also examined for application to a cathode material for Li-ion batteries. The capacity of Nb2O5-1 was 208 mA h g–1 at C/10, and the deposition of Au NPs improved the capacity to 232 mA h g–1 (Au/Nb2O5-1) due to the improved electrical conductivity by Au NPs. Furthermore, Au/Nb2O5-1 recorded high capacity at a high rate (169.7 mA h g–1 at 5 C) and good cyclic performance. The capacity of Au/Nb2O5-1 was higher than that of other Au/Nb2O5 samples, and the order was related to the order of catalytic activities for CO oxidation. Accordingly, the capacity increased in the order of Au/Nb2O5-1> Au/Nb2O5-4 > Au/Nb2O5-2. XPS and CO-DRIFT revealed that a larger amount of Nb4+ was contained in Au/Nb2O5-1 than other Nb2O5 samples, suggesting that a larger amount of oxygen vacancies was formed on the Nb2O5-1 surface. Oxygen vacancies play an important role in O2 activation in CO oxidation and for improvement of electrochemical performance. Therefore, the catalytic activity for CO oxidation and the battery performance were correlated, and it can be said that the higher the catalytic activity Au/Nb2O5 is, the higher is the capacity of Au/Nb2O5. We expect that our findings will contribute to the development of cathode materials, not only Nb2O5 but also other metal oxide materials, for Li-ion batteries. 5 Declaration of Competing Interest The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. coredata.dc:description: We prepared a series of Nb2O5 polymorphs by the sol-gel method and the sol-gel hydrothermal method. Gold nanoparticles supported on Nb2O5 were prepared by solid grinding method. Au on pseudohexagonal (TT-phase) Nb2O5 containing an amorphous phase exhibited higher catalytic activity for CO oxidation than did other Au/Nb2O5 polymorphs. For the electrochemical properties for cathode materials of Li-ion batteries, Nb2O5 (TT) exhibited high capacity of 208 mA h g-1, and the deposition of Au onto Nb2O5 (TT) improved the capacity to 232 mA h g-1. Capacity and CO oxidation activity were related; the higher the catalytic activity Au/Nb2O5 shows, the higher is the discharging capacity. From the characterization results, Nb2O5 (TT) contains oxygen vacancies (Nb4+ sites), and the oxygen vacancies of Nb2O5 (TT) would play an important role for CO oxidation and the performance for Li-ion batteries.
coredata.dc:title: Gold Nanoparticles Supported on Nb2O5 for Low-Temperature CO Oxidation and as Cathode Materials for Li-ion Batteries
